title: 107_s487
content: SECTION 1. EDUCATIONAL USE COPYRIGHT EXEMPTION. The Technology, Education, and Copyright Harmonization Act of 2001 exempts certain performances and displays for educational purposes under Section 110 of title 17, United States Code. This includes exceptions for works used in mediated instructional activities transmitted via digital networks, as well as performances using copies or phonorecords that are not lawfully made and acquired. The Technology, Education, and Copyright Harmonization Act of 2001 exempts performances and displays for educational purposes under Section 110 of title 17, United States Code. This includes exceptions for works used in mediated instructional activities transmitted via digital networks, as well as performances using copies or phonorecords that are not lawfully made and acquired. The Act allows the performance or display of literary or musical works in a classroom setting as part of systematic instructional activities. The Technology, Education, and Copyright Harmonization Act of 2001 exempts transmissions for educational purposes to limited recipients and requires institutions to implement copyright policies and provide educational materials on copyright laws. The Technology, Education, and Copyright Harmonization Act of 2001 exempts educational transmissions from copyright restrictions and mandates institutions to implement copyright policies for educational materials. This includes applying technological measures to prevent retention of works beyond the class session. The Technology, Education, and Copyright Harmonization Act of 2001 exempts educational transmissions from copyright restrictions and mandates institutions to implement copyright policies for educational materials. This includes applying technological measures to prevent unauthorized dissemination of works. The term 'mediated instructional activities' refers to the performance or display of a work by digital transmission under this section. The term 'mediated instructional activities' refers to the performance or display of a work by digital transmission as part of the class experience, supervised by the instructor, and similar to a live classroom setting. It does not include activities using textbooks or course materials typically purchased by students for independent use. The accreditation for post-secondary education is determined by recognized agencies, while for elementary or secondary education, it is recognized by state certification procedures. Governmental bodies and accredited educational institutions are not liable for infringement due to temporary storage of material in digital transmissions authorized under paragraph (2). (c) Ephemeral Recordings.-- Section 112 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to allow for temporary storage of material in digital transmissions authorized under paragraph (2), with restrictions on accessibility and retention periods. Nonprofit educational institutions can make copies of digital or analog works for transmissions authorized under section 110(2) without infringing copyright, as long as the copies are used solely by the institution and not reproduced further. Nonprofit educational institutions are allowed to convert print or analog works into digital formats for transmissions authorized under section 110(2), under certain conditions. This includes situations where no digital version of the work is available to the institution or the available digital version is protected by technological measures. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to section 802(c) of title 17, United States Code. The Undersecretary of Commerce for Intellectual Property, in consultation with the Register of Copyrights, must submit a report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The report will describe technological protection systems for digitized copyrighted works, including upgradeable and self-repairing systems developed in private industry-led entities through a consensus process. No recommendations or comparisons will be included in the report. The report under this subsection is solely for providing information to Congress and should not impact any provisions of title 17, United States Code. It does not include recommendations or comparisons of commercially available products. The Senate passed the document on June 7, 2001, attested by Gary Sisco, Secretary.
